readflexfile 0.2.0

Flatten FlexFile and Quantity Data Report

Source: R/flatten_ff.R
flatten_lists.Rd

Create separate data frames for the FlexFile and the Quantity Data Report. These functions merge together many tables into a single one more useful for analysis. This generally involves joining together numerous ID fields. Actuals and forecasts are also stacked into a single table.

flatten_ff() creates a single flat file for working with FlexFile data.

flatten_qdr() creates a single flat file for working with FlexFile quantity data.

flatten_ff(flexfile, .id = "doc_id")

flatten_qdr(quantity_data, .id = "doc_id")

Arguments

flexfile

A list of one or more FlexFiles imported through the read_ff function.
.id

The name of the ID column which uniquely identifies a flexfile.
quantity_data

A list of one or more Quantity Data Reports created from the read_ff function.

Value

A data frame with the flattened flexfile or quantity data.

Examples

if (FALSE) {
# Flatten one FlexFile
file <- system.file("extdata", "Sample_FlexFile_A.zip", package = "flexample")

flat_flex_file <- read_ff(file) %>%
  add_id_col(var = "doc_id") %>%
  flatten_ff()

#Flatten mutliple FlexFiles

files <- system.file("extdata", package = "flexample")

flat_flexfiles <- read_folder(files, read_ff) %>%
  listindex_to_col(var = "doc_id") %>%
  stack_ff() %>%
  flatten_ff()
}
if (FALSE) {
# read a sample quantity report
file <- system.file("extdata", "Sample_Quantity_A.zip", package = "flexample")

flat_flex_file <- read_ff(file) %>%
  add_id_col() %>%
  flatten_qdr()
}
